sub_topic: Quantification of the amount of a substance in a sample using gravimetric analysis
message_1: What is the mass of copper in a sample of brass alloy that weighs 10.00 grams, given that the sample contains 70% copper and 30% zinc by weight, using gravimetric analysis?
message_2:
To determine the mass of copper in the brass alloy sample, we can use the given percentage composition of the alloy. Since the sample contains 70% copper by weight, we can calculate the mass of copper as follows:

Mass of copper = (Percentage of copper / 100) × Total mass of the sample
Mass of copper = (70 / 100) × 10.00 grams
Mass of copper = 0.70 × 10.00 grams
Mass of copper = 7.00 grams

So, the mass of copper in the 10.00-gram brass alloy sample is 7.00 grams.
